SENT.plain: Hyaluronic acid, a major component of the brain extracellular matrix, is a regulator of angiogenesis, cell differentiation and migration
We used the rat middle cerebral artery occlusion model to show hyaluronan accumulation in stroke-affected areas
Using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction and Western blotting we showed up-regulation of hyaluronidase-1 and 2 between 1 h and 21 days after stroke
Hyaluronidase-1 was up-regulated earlier than hyaluronidase-2
The hyaladherins, receptor for hyaluronan-mediated motility and CD44 were also increased after stroke
Using immunohistochemistry, we showed association of hyaluronidases 1/2 and hyaladherins with neurons in the infarcted and peri-infarcted regions and hyaluronidase-1 with microvessels
Hyaluronan synthesis and degradation in the stroke hemisphere might have an impact on neuronal survival, angiogenesis and general tissue remodelling after stroke
